After the trials on last Thursday, Dr. John C. French, faculty
member of the Debating Council,
announced the line-up of the 1918
Debating Team. The affirmative
team will consist of Morton K.
Rothschild, chairman, Charles S.
Miegel, and Adolf L. Hamburger,
alternate. The negative team will
consist of Leo W. Simon, chairman; Joseph M. Berkowitz, and
Henry S. Miller, alternate.
The arrangements for the traditional triangular debate between
the Universities of Virginia and
North Carolina and the Johns
Hopkins University have been
completed. It is customary for
each university to be represented by
both an affirmative and a negative
team, both of which debate away
from home. The Hopkins affirmative team will meet Virginia at
Chapel Hill, North Carolina; while
the negative team will journey to
Charlottesville to meet North Carolina. The subject of the debate is
based on the question of conscription of labor; the date is Saturday, April 27. The judges, of whom
there are five, and• who are selected from the faculty of the University where the debate takes place
have not yet been announced.
Last year the triangular debate
was cancelled in accordance with
the policy of suspending intercollegiate contests on account of war
prepa rations, but until that time
Hopkins had consistently finished
first in the league. It is hoped that
this year's team will live up to the
traditions set up by its predecessors. All of the members of the
team have had experience in interclass debating, and there is one
man left from last year's team.
It was hoped for a time that
Frank V. Morley, star of the recent Adams interclass debate,
would be able to hold down a
speaker's job on the team; but unfortunately the lacrosse team
needs his services on the same day
on which the debate is scheduled.

The seniors in the Engineering
Department will leave Baltimore
on April 10 on a trip to Pittsburgh. The purpose of the trip
is to visit some of the largest
plants in the country and see various processes in the steel and
shipbuilding industry. Drs. Kowenhoven and Christie will accompany the men. There will be students of civil, electrical and mechanical engineering.
The party will leave Union Station on the Pennsylvania R. R. on
April 10 at 8.22 P. M. They will
arrive at Wilmerding the following morning, where they will visit
the Westinghouse Air Brake Company.
In the afternoon the men will
go to the Westinghouse Electrical
and Manufacturing Company,
which is in reality two plants. The
electric plant makes nothing but
electrical machines, while the
machines company manufactures
steam turbines, condensers and
gear sets for ships.
On the morning of the 12th the
National Tube Company at McKeesport will be inspected. - All
sorts of steel pipes are made here,
and it is the boast of this corporation that they have every process
from the ore to the finished product.” Blast furnaces, Bessemer
converters and the Spellerizing
process may all be seen here. The
fact that there are 45 acres under
one roof gives a vague idea of the
size of the plant. The next place
on the list is the McKeesport Tin
Plate Company, where sheets are
made for tin cans.
Orr April 13 the students will go
to Ambridge, where the American
Bridge Company is located. Here
ships are fabricated, a process
hich corresponds to the assembling of Ford machines. The seniors will conclude the trip with a
visit to the A. M. Byers Co., where
wrought iron is made. A large
part of our wrought iron which
used to come from Sweden is now

That the question of a league of
nations to insure the peace of the
world in the future is no longer an
academic one, but one which is occupying the serious thought of
leading governments, was brought
out clearly in the last of the "Aspects of the World War" lecturesWar" by Mr. Theodore Marburg,

Hall.

address was "Plans to Discourage

the ,formation of some kind of
league or pact—whether in the nature of international police or of
an economic character—would be
one of the almost inevitable outcomes of of the present war; it is
the only way to prevent another
such disaster.

the form of the Versailles Council.

things which it is given to us to

BATTALION NEWS
Monday Drill.

Last Monday's drill was devoted
exclusively to squad movements in
preparation for the coming inspection and .review. Particular emphasis was laid on the extended order or skirmish line movements,
for in a previous drill the squads
had been separately instructed in
all the close order movements. For
instruction in the open order work,
one squad was marched out in
front of the company and was put
through the different manoevers.
After seeing the orders executed properly, the other squads
were separated and instructed as
units by officers or sergeants.
First the orders were given verbally and later the whistle and
arm signals were used. Since on
the actual firing line hardly any
verbal commands are audible the
arm signals are used altogether.
From time to time the officers of
the staff visited the separate
squads to correct mistakes.
Battalion Builds System of Trenches.

mere modeling in relief of a certain bit of country, but the situation
and
construction
of

were modeled showingevery detail.

huge expenditure of effort by the
battalion last spring, for the sand
table trenches were only an inch
or less deep. Barbed-wire entanglements were of course placed
wherever the tactical situation demanded. While the class was at
work pictures of it were taken for
the War Department. The next
morning several members of the
battalion were seen amusing themselves by inserting gun powder
beneath the trenches, lighting a
fust, and blowing them to kingdom
come. The whole effect and the
shell holes left behind were most
realistic.

Why The News-Letter is Late.

When THE, NliWS- LETTER, published in the interest of, as wellas
by the students of the Johns Hopkins University,appears at the end
instead of at the beginning of the
week, the students expect an explanation of the reasons for the
delay. It is our purpose to present
to the student body a detailed explanation of these reasons - with
the purpose, not of apologizing nor
of enlisting sympathy, but of
arousing a general demand for
the abolition of the existing evils.
The immediate cause of the
long-delayed appearance of THE
NEWS LETTER, the cause of the last
24 hours' delay, was the demand
of the State Senate Journal for
priority at the printer's office. But
this source of delay was accidental, comparatively trivial, unavoidable, and dependent on a
deeper, underlying cause. The underlying cause of the delay ;is
directly traceable to THE NEWSLETTER board; and it is there that
the blame should be placed.
Now, it is hardly necessary to
explain to our readers that the
fundamental requisite of a newspaper is "copy" or to use a less
technical term, news stories. The
nature and truth of news stories
varies with different papers, but
the prime requisite is always the
same. It is also desirable that
you should remember that a college newspaper cannot be "set up"
or composed, organized, and print-

ed on the day that it is to appear.
A college paper is not published by
an independent concern, but that
explains why copy is "ordered in"
on Thursday evening before the
appearance of the issue.
In the case of the last issue, of
more than 25 assignments that
were distributed early Monday
morning to associate editors and
candidates, only two were received
at the time they were due—namely, 5 o'clock on Thursday. There
was no additional copy up to 1
o'clock—i.e.,in time for the printer to set it up on Friday. The utter
impossibility of publishing THE
NEWS LETTER with two columns of
news is quite apparent. But this
is only one of a series of instances
that have prevented the timely
appearance Of THE NEWS-LETTER.
On the week before there were seven important assignments that
were not covered at all. In such
cases it becomes necessary for the
editor-in-chief to gather up secondhand and hastily written accounts
that are never satisfactory.
One would think that THE
NEWS-LETTER had anticipated such
difficulties and had formulated a
means of preventing it. But it has
never been possible for us to excavate .a constitution or even a
minute book that might harbor a
puilitive measure for indifferent
editors. There are, to be sure, unwritten laws providing for the automatic elimination of men who
fail to regularly attend board
meetings Or to regularly turn in
copy. But those laws are dependent, strangely enough, for their
enforcement upon the sanction of
the recalcitrant members. It is,
then only natural to find that
they simply cannot be enforced.
This explains why THE NEWSLETTER intends to ask the Student
Council, under Article IV, See. 2,
of its Constitution, which appears
in another column of this issue, to
help find a remedy for existing
conditions. It believes there is an
urgent need for reform in its organization, and that the entire student body is in sympathy with a
movement that will not only meet
the present exigency, but a great
many problems that will beggar
solution in the future.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—There may be some question as to the exact meaning of

what, specifically, it comprehends
but whatever may be the true interpretation of that code, there is
no doubt that it is looked upon
as an unalienable right of Hopkins
undergraduates. Therefore, when
a class is told, before a "quiz,"
that the honor system must be discarded, it is a humiliation commensurate only with the seriousness of the indictment that the
Johns Hopkins student body is
unfit for the exercise of a voluntary code of honor.
We are told that in the last examinations cheating was discovered; therefore, we are not to have
the privilege of the honor system!
Because some violations of the
code have occurred, the entire undergraduate body is not to be credited with an appreciation of the
value of honorable conduct! I
have been told, "You have no kick
coming, because there was 'cribbing' in the exams."
But we have a "kick coming,"
if we are all to be treated as potential crooks because a few did
not play fair! Could anything be
more unjust than to abolish a
standard of conduct and code of
honor of an entire group because
of a few irresponsible members?
The thing to do is to preserve the
high code of honor, and to expel
those who violate it.
In the second place, the very
reason given in the answer above,
that there was "cribbing," proves
that we have a kick coming
against a system which permits

leave the room during an examination ; beyond this, the notion is

system, in which there are definite
obligations on all members, and
which will rely for its effectiveness, not on the threat of its being
taken away, but on the moral
force of the entire student body behind it. The honor system is more
than a convenience for the holding of examinations, and a compliment on the character of the stu-.

Why The News-Letter is Late.

When THE, NliWS- LETTER, published in the interest of, as wellas

delay. It is our purpose to present
to the student body a detailed explanation of these reasons - with
the purpose, not of apologizing nor
of enlisting sympathy, but of
arousing a general demand for
the abolition of the existing evils.
The immediate cause of the
long-delayed appearance of THE

deeper, underlying cause. The underlying cause of the delay ;is

nature and truth of news stories

the prime requisite is always the
same. It is also desirable that
you should remember that a college newspaper cannot be "set up"

an independent concern, but that

candidates, only two were received
at the time they were due—namely, 5 o'clock on Thursday. There
was no additional copy up to 1
o'clock—i.e.,in time for the printer to set it up on Friday. The utter
impossibility of publishing THE
NEWS LETTER with two columns of
news is quite apparent. But this
is only one of a series of instances
that have prevented the timely
appearance Of THE NEWS-LETTER.
On the week before there were seven important assignments that
were not covered at all. In such
cases it becomes necessary for the
editor-in-chief to gather up secondhand and hastily written accounts

difficulties and had formulated a

puilitive measure for indifferent
editors. There are, to be sure, unwritten laws providing for the automatic elimination of men who
fail to regularly attend board
meetings Or to regularly turn in
copy. But those laws are dependent, strangely enough, for their
enforcement upon the sanction of
the recalcitrant members. It is,
then only natural to find that
they simply cannot be enforced.
This explains why THE NEWSLETTER intends to ask the Student
Council, under Article IV, See. 2,

in another column of this issue, to
help find a remedy for existing
conditions. It believes there is an
urgent need for reform in its organization, and that the entire student body is in sympathy with a
movement that will not only meet
the present exigency, but a great
many problems that will beggar
solution in the future.

Protests the Abuse of the Honor System.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—There may be some question as to the exact meaning of
the "honor system," and as to
what, specifically, it comprehends
but whatever may be the true interpretation of that code, there is
no doubt that it is looked upon
as an unalienable right of Hopkins
undergraduates. Therefore, when
a class is told, before a "quiz,"
that the honor system must be discarded, it is a humiliation commensurate only with the seriousness of the indictment that the
Johns Hopkins student body is
unfit for the exercise of a voluntary code of honor.
We are told that in the last examinations cheating was discovered; therefore, we are not to have
the privilege of the honor system!
Because some violations of the
code have occurred, the entire undergraduate body is not to be credited with an appreciation of the
value of honorable conduct! I
have been told, "You have no kick
coming, because there was 'cribbing' in the exams."
But we have a "kick coming,"
if we are all to be treated as potential crooks because a few did
not play fair! Could anything be
more unjust than to abolish a
standard of conduct and code of
honor of an entire group because
of a few irresponsible members?
The thing to do is to preserve the
high code of honor, and to expel
those who violate it.
In the second place, the very
reason given in the answer above,
that there was "cribbing," proves
that we have a kick coming
against a system which permits
such a thing to go on. What we
need is a definite and unequivocal
formulation of the obligations of
the honor system. The important
difference between such a code and
the old police method, from impressions gained at Hopkins,
seems to be the fact that one may
leave the room during an examination ; beyond this, the notion is
hazy. Let us have a real, vertebrated, forty-two-centimeter honor
system, in which there are definite
obligations on all members, and
which will rely for its effectiveness, not on the threat of its being
taken away, but on the moral
force of the entire student body behind it. The honor system is more
than a convenience for the holding of examinations, and a compliment on the character of the stu-.
